title: 2014 UEFA Super Cup
text:
The 2014 UEFA Super Cup was the 39th edition of the <a href="UEFA%20Super%20Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a>, an annual <a href="association%20football">football</a> match organised by <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a> and contested by the reigning champions of the two main <a href="Europe">Europe</a>an club competitions, the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> and the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a>. The match featured two Spanish teams <a href="Real%20Madrid%20CF">Real Madrid</a> and <a href="Sevilla%20FC">Sevilla</a>, the winners of the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2013–14 UEFA Champions League</a> and the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2013–14 UEFA Europa League</a> respectively. It was played at the <a href="Cardiff%20City%20Stadium">Cardiff City Stadium</a> in <a href="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>, Wales, on 12 August 2014. The date was moved from Friday in late August in previous years, to mid-August starting this year, following the removal of the August international friendly date in the new <a href="FIFA%20International%20Match%20Calendar">FIFA International Match Calendar</a>.
Real Madrid won 2–0 to win their second UEFA Super Cup, with both goals by <a href="Cristiano%20Ronaldo">Cristiano Ronaldo</a>.
Venue.
The <a href="Cardiff%20City%20Stadium">Cardiff City Stadium</a> was announced as the venue of the Super Cup at the UEFA Executive Committee meeting on 30 June 2012. This was the first UEFA Super Cup hosted in Wales.
The Cardiff City Stadium opened in July 2009 on the site of the <a href="Cardiff%20Athletics%20Stadium">Cardiff Athletics Stadium</a>. It is the home stadium of <a href="Cardiff%20City%20F.C.">Cardiff City</a>. The stadium had a capacity of 33,000 after expansion work.
Pre-match.
Ticketing.
The international ticket sales phase for the general public ran from 5 to 27 June 2014. Tickets were available in three price categories: <a href="Pound%20sterling">£</a>110, £75, and £40.
Officials.
England's <a href="Mark%20Clattenburg">Mark Clattenburg</a> was appointed by UEFA as the referee of the match, accompanied by an all-English team of officials: assistant referees Simon Beck and Stuart Burt, fourth official Darren England, and additional assistant referees <a href="Michael%20Oliver%20%28referee%29">Michael Oliver</a> and <a href="Anthony%20Taylor%20%28referee%29">Anthony Taylor</a>.
The match was the first in a UEFA club competition to use <a href="vanishing%20spray">vanishing spray</a>.
Match.
Team selection.
Real Madrid midfielder <a href="Xabi%20Alonso">Xabi Alonso</a> was suspended for the match, due to breaches of conduct in the Champions League Final, for which he was also suspended.
New signings <a href="Toni%20Kroos">Toni Kroos</a> and <a href="James%20Rodr%C3%ADguez">James Rodríguez</a> made their competitive debuts for Real Madrid; another new signing, <a href="Keylor%20Navas">Keylor Navas</a>, was an unused substitute. Sevilla gave competitive debuts to <a href="Denis%20Su%C3%A1rez">Denis Suárez</a>, <a href="Aleix%20Vidal">Aleix Vidal</a> and <a href="Grzegorz%20Krychowiak">Grzegorz Krychowiak</a>, as well as substitute <a href="Iago%20Aspas">Iago Aspas</a>. <a href="Nicol%C3%A1s%20Pareja">Nicolás Pareja</a> and <a href="Daniel%20Carri%C3%A7o">Daniel Carriço</a> represented Sevilla for the first time since their loans were made permanent.
